----- Revenues 84% 5 % 11% Operating costs 80% 6 % 14% Based on the year ended December 31, 2021, a one cent change in the U.S. dollar/Euro exchange rate would have impacted revenues by approximately $2 million annually, with an immaterial impact on operating income/(loss). _Interest Rate Risk_ We continually review our fixed and variable rate debt along with related hedging opportunities in order to ensure our portfolio is appropriately balanced as part of our overall interest rate risk management strategy and through this process we consider both short-term and long-term considerations in the United States and global financial markets in making adjustments to our tolerable exposures to interest rate risk. At September 30, 2022, we had $2,096 million in carrying value of floating-rate debt under our senior secured credit facilities of which $800 million was subject to effective floating-fixed interest rate swaps. At December 31, 2021, we had $2,093 million of floating-rate debt under our senior secured credit facilities, of which $1,050 million was subject to effective floatingfixed interest rate swaps. These derivatives have been designated as interest rate cash flow hedges and fix the LIBOR-related portion of interest rates of a corresponding amount of our variable-rate-debt. A one percent increase in interest rates applied to our floating rate indebtedness would therefore increase annual interest expense by approximately $10 million ($21 million without giving effect to any of our interest rate swaps). In anticipation of the closing of the Transaction, which occurred on October 11, 2022, we terminated all of the outstanding interest rate swaps on October 6, 2022 for net proceeds of $10 million. Derivative instruments involve, to varying degrees, elements of non-performance, or credit risk. We do not believe that we currently face a significant risk of loss in the event of non-performance by the counterparties associated with these instruments, as these transactions were executed with a diversified group of major financial institutions with a minimum investment-grade or better credit rating. Our credit risk exposure is managed through the continuous monitoring of our exposures to such counterparties. _Equity Price Risk_ We are not exposed to material equity price risk. -----

Nielsen serves the world’s media and content ecosystem and is a global leader in audience measurement, data and analytics. Through our understanding of people and their behaviors across all channels and platforms, we empower our clients with independent and actionable intelligence so that they can connect and engage with their audiences now and in the future. We have become a household name that has built a market-standard position driven by a long track record of execution, adapting through numerous shifts in media consumption. For the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, our pro forma total revenue was $3,541 million and our Pro forma adjusted EBITDA was $1,687 million. See “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated and Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information” for definitions of our non-GAAP financial measures and reconciliations of our non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP financial measures. In the United States, which is the world’s largest market for television programming, broadcasters and cable networks use our television audience estimates as a primary currency of choice to establish the value of their airtime and more effectively schedule and promote their programming through ad price intermediation and delivery validation. We provide a holistic and objective understanding of the media industry to our various client segments. Our data is used by our publishing clients to understand their audiences, establish the value of their advertising inventory and maximize the value of their content. Our data is used by our marketer and advertiser agency clients to plan and optimize their spend and by our content creator clients to inform decisions and identify trends. We have operations in more than 55 countries, with our registered office located in London, the United Kingdom and headquarters located in New York, United States.

- **_Inclusion and representation. We believe our data is representative of the entire media ecosystem. Ad buyers and sellers do not have access to market wide viewership data, requiring a third-party aggregator to provide common metrics. We seek to ensure that all of our products are representative of diverse populations and offer greater demographic representation, higher quality and more actionable insights for better decision making. - **_Breadth of Offerings. Our measurement, data and analytics solutions are deeply embedded into our clients’ workflows and offer a 360-degree view of the audience that we believe cannot be found by a single provider anywhere else. With products that span the full marketing cycle, we believe we are uniquely positioned to help marketers drive growth with the confidence that they are spending their dollars efficiently and effectively. ----- - **_Enhanced Data Assets and Measurement Science. Our extensive portfolio of decades of consumer behavioral and transactional data enables us to provide critical information to our clients and allows for long-term historical comparability. Our big data sets are validated by behaviors of over 100,000 people on our panels, allowing us to provide persons-level measurement that is representative of all audiences. - **_Global Scale and Brand. We believe we are the currency of choice in the U.S. media market and uniquely positioned to deliver the most reliable deduplication metrics across linear and digital platforms. Our footprint, independence, credibility and leading market positions continue to contribute to our long-term growth and strong operating margins in the evolving global media landscape. We believe the industry wants a single holistic view of the market as media fragmentation continues and the landscape gets more complex, and we think Nielsen, through Nielsen ONE, is uniquely positioned to offer this. - **_Strong, Diversified Client Relationships. Many of the world’s largest and emerging media companies, marketers and advertising agencies rely on our information and analytics to create value for their business. We have historically generated stable revenue streams that are characterized by multi-year contracts and high renewal rates. Approximately 80% of the revenue base for the upcoming year is committed under contract at the beginning of each year, while the average length of relationship with our top five clients is more than 30 years. - **_Scalable Operating Model. Our global presence and operating model allow us to scale our services and solutions rapidly and efficiently. Our flexible architecture allows us to incorporate leading third-party technologies as well as data from external sources and enables our clients to use our technology and solutions on their own technology platforms. We believe Nielsen is embedded in the advertising ecosystem and our clients’ business models, helping to secure our position as the industry standard. Note: Represents data for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2021. Data reflects revised mapping and adjusts for business exits made in 2020 and 2021.

Our clients require an increasing amount of data and analytics to set strategy and direct operations as competition for audiences’ time and spend intensifies. The media landscape is undergoing significant change, as viewing fragments and streaming grows. This has resulted in a large market for business information and insight, which we believe will continue to grow with our clients. Our clients are predominantly media publishers and advertisers and their agencies, although we see demand increasing from content creators, owners, distributors and other ecosystem participants as well. ----- - **_The landscape is dynamic and changing. Consumers are rapidly changing their media consumption patterns and the proliferation of new formats and channels has led to increased time spent with media, and the six largest U.S. media companies in aggregate grew faster in 2021 than in the prior years as they added digital solutions. In addition, simultaneous usage of more than one screen is becoming a regular aspect of daily consumer media consumption. We believe our distinct ability to provide independent cross-media audience measurement and metrics helps clients better understand, adapt to and profit from the continued transformation of the global media landscape. - **_Consumers are more connected, informed and in control. Nearly 60% of the global population—over 4 billion people—use the internet, and over 3 billion are digital video viewers. Advances in technology have given consumers a greater level of control of when, where and how they consume information and interact with media and brands. These shifts in behavior create significant complexities for our clients. Our broad portfolio of measurement and analytical services enables our clients to engage consumers with more impact and efficiency and to actively participate in and shape conversations with their audiences. - **_Increasing amounts of consumer information are leading to new marketing approaches. The advent of the internet and digital platforms has created rapid growth in consumer data, and as a result, companies are looking for real-time access to more granular levels of data to understand growth opportunities quickly and precisely. This presents a significant opportunity for us to work with companies to effectively manage, integrate and analyze large amounts of information and extract meaningful insights that allow marketers to generate profitable growth. According to research from MoffettNathanson, U.S. TV ad spend (Linear plus AVOD) is expected to grow to approximately $86 billion in 2022, up from $81 billion in 2021. Our audience estimates are the primary metrics used to determine the value of programming and advertising in the U.S. television advertising marketplace. Furthermore, approximately 95% of U.S. TV ad spend in 2021 relied on Nielsen data. Including the United States, our technology is used to measure television viewing in 37 countries. We also measure markets that account for approximately 70% of global TV ad spend, according to eMarketer research, and offer measurement and analytic services in more than 55 countries, including the United States. In addition, according to research from MoffettNathanson, U.S. digital ad spend (Video and Other) will grow to approximately $192 billion in 2022, up from $167 billion in 2021. Nielsen Digital Ad Ratings are used by 21 of the top 25 global advertisers by total ad spend to help determine the effectiveness of their digital spend, and we continue to expand coverage, with the ability to measure approximately 90% of total video digital spend across computer, mobile and CTV based on Nielsen estimates and eMarketer research. Our audience estimates are the primary metrics used to determine the value of programming and advertising in the U.S. audio advertising marketplace. ----- Sources: MoffettNathanson, eMarketer. (1) Includes YouTube, Snap and portions of other social media platforms. (2) Includes search, Google Network, and portions of social media platforms. (3) Does not include pure SVOD/subscription video on demand, which do not contain ads. (4) Advertising within short-form video (e.g., YouTube, social media video) and live streaming (e.g., Twitch). (5) Primarily web-based advertising including paid search, social media (non-video), banner/display ads, and other browser-based advertising. (6) Audio content delivered over-the-air via traditional radio and digital content delivered via streaming audio and apps (e.g., podcasts). (7) Compilation of print and digital newspapers / magazines and other advertising including billboards and public space “outdoor” venues.

Nielsen serves the world’s media and content ecosystem and is the gold standard in audience measurement, data and analytics. We provide viewership and listening measurement data and analytics primarily to media publishers and marketers and their advertising agencies for linear television, streaming, digital (which includes computer, mobile and CTV) and listening platforms. Our business consists of two major product categories: One Measurement Solutions, or “Measurement,” and Impact Marketing Solutions / Gracenote Content Solutions, or “Impact / Content.” Measurement measures viewing and listening of ads and content. Impact connects viewing and listening of advertising to consumer outcomes, and Gracenote enables audience discovery of content and drives key business decision-making around content. Previously, Measurement was referred to as “Audience Measurement” and Impact / Content was referred to as “Outcomes / Content.” Nielsen’s media ratings and position as market currency of choice are supported by market-leading panels and the industry’s largest collection of big data and backed by over 50 years of longitudinal data and intellectual property development.

Our measurement solutions have evolved along with changes in consumer viewing and listening behavior, enabling Nielsen to capture consumption of ads and content across all available platforms and mediums. _Cross-Media Measurement_ In December 2020, we announced our plans to launch a single, cross-media solution, Nielsen ONE, to drive more comparable and comprehensive metrics across platforms. We believe our transformative cross-media solution ----- will evolve the current metrics that underpin the more than $100 billion video advertising ecosystem using a phased approach. We plan to leverage our existing authority in media measurement to accelerate this new initiative’s growth, with anchor clients that have long-term digital-focused contracts. We expect to be successful in transitioning all or substantially all of the industry to cross-media metrics by the end of 2024. Cross-media measurement is a critical pain point for advertisers. Measurement today often varies by medium, with different units/means of counting applied across varying channels. Further inconsistency is driven by differing definitions of units, which leads to inconsistent reporting and actionability. Given ongoing media fragmentation and massive shifts in consumer viewer behavior, we believe advertisers and publishers want comparable and deduplicated metrics across platforms. With Nielsen ONE, advertisers and publishers will be able to transact using a single metric across linear, digital and streaming that is trusted, independent and standardized across the industry. With a single, consistent, deduplicated number, advertisers will have visibility into total video consumption regardless of platform or device, along with a better understanding of unique audiences, and the ability to better understand frequency and reduce double counting, inflated metrics and advertising waste. Publishers will be able to provide more ad options for buyers and improve the overall viewer experience. We expect that this new offering will improve advertisers’ ability to attribute ad performance and measure ROI by channel. Nielsen ONE will also underpin our Impact Marketing Solutions, thus enabling the industry to optimize media plans and maximize performance across platforms. _Television Audience Measurement_ We are a global leader in television audience measurement, and we believe we are the currency of choice for U.S. broadcasters and cable networks. Advertisers use this information to plan television advertising campaigns, evaluate the effectiveness of their commercial messages and negotiate advertising rates. We provide two principal television measurement services in the United States: measurement of national television audiences; and measurement of local television audiences in local television markets. Our approach combines the scale of big data from set-top-boxes and smart TVs and granular insights from real people through our household panel to deliver comprehensive measurement. Our television panels ensure inclusion across all platforms including cable, satellite, MVPD, Over-the-air, OTT streaming and OOH. The panel is a key competitive advantage that provides persons-level measurement and leverages U.S. census data and sampling to accurately represent the country’s evolving demographics and accurately estimate total television viewership. Using our modernized panel, advanced machine learning models and our identifiers resolution system, Nielsen delivers audience behavior metrics allowing for a more complete view of the media marketplace. We have made significant investments over decades to build an infrastructure that can accurately and efficiently track ----- television audience viewing, a process that has become increasingly complex as the industry has converted to digital transmission and integrated new technologies allowing for developments such as time-shifted viewing. Our measurement techniques are constantly evolving to account for new television viewing behavior, increased fragmentation and new media technologies. The addition of linear addressable impressions to national television measurement will help unlock new value and flexibility for publishers and advertisers to insert addressable ads in any commercial minute they choose. Through Nielsen’s measurement of both targeted and linear audiences, advertisers can better monetize advertising impressions without risking measurement of linear audiences. Our technology is used to measure television viewing in 37 countries, including the United States and countries throughout Latin America, Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia. The international television audience measurement industry operates on a different model than in the United States. In many international markets, a joint industry committee of broadcasters in each individual country selects a single official audience measurement provider, which is designated the “currency” through an organized bidding process that is typically revisited every several years. Nielsen believes that its currency will become more global as digital becomes more global. _Digital Audience Measurement_ We are a global provider of digital audience measurement across computers, mobile and streaming via connected devices. Over the past several years Nielsen has experienced rapid growth with many of the leading technology and digital media companies, and these fast-growing entities represent a growing share of Nielsen’s revenue base. We employ a variety of measurement offerings to provide media companies, marketers and brands with metrics to better understand the behavior of digital audiences. In early 2021, Nielsen introduced its new digital methodology that underpins its digital measurement suite. The new methodology leverages Nielsen’s media panel truth sets, census data collection technology, proprietary bias correction and calibration models and diverse thirdparty partner assets. DAR provides age and gender audience demographics, with key metrics such as reach, frequency, Gross Rating Points and on-target percentage. DAR is used in 37 countries, with South Korea, Denmark and Sweden being the most recent markets to launch. Overall, Nielsen has the ability to measure approximately 90% of total video digital ad spend across computer, mobile and CTV. ----- _Streaming Measurement_ According to The Gauge, Nielsen’s monthly total TV and streaming snapshot, as of July 2022, consumers now spend approximately 35% of their total TV time engaging with streaming content. To address this growing part of the media landscape, we have a comprehensive suite of streaming solutions through which media buyers and sellers make critical strategy decisions and content creators and studios can make informed programming and content distribution decisions. Additionally, with Nielsen’s offerings, streaming services can prove their audience profile against competitors and guide content and subscriber acquisition strategies. Nielsen Streaming Platform Ratings uses people-powered panels and proprietary metering technology to measure what content is streamed, the device used to stream (e.g., smart TVs, connected devices, video game consoles) and the streaming source application. Nielsen Streaming Content Ratings delivers program and episodelevel measurement. Nielsen’s DAR for CTV delivers audience measurement for streaming ads on CTV devices, with the ability to measure 75% of CTV media spend in the United States. Nielsen Streaming Signals, launched in January 2022, is a real-time, pre-ad insertion signal of who is watching what TV content within a household. By providing person-level demographic predictions of who is watching CTV content (that can include age, gender, race, ethnicity, and geography), we enable more precise and efficient targeted advertising by our CTV clients. _Audio Audience Measurement_ We provide independent measurement and consumer research primarily servicing radio, advertisers and advertising agencies in the audio industry. We estimate the size and composition of radio audiences in local markets and of audiences to network radio programming and commercials in the United States. We provide our syndicated radio ratings services (our local and network radio audience ratings services) in local markets in the United States to radio broadcasters, advertising agencies, and advertisers. Our national services estimate the size and demographic composition of national radio audiences and the size and composition of audiences of network radio programs and commercials. Broadcasters use our data primarily to price and sell advertising time, and advertising agencies and advertisers use our data in purchasing advertising time. We have developed our electronic PPM technology, which we deploy across many of our customer offerings and have licensed to other media information services companies to use in their media audience ratings services in countries outside of the United States. We have commercialized our PPM ratings service in 48 of the largest radio markets in the United States. Nielsen’s PPM technology is also used commercially for national television OOH, as well as integrated into local television measurement as of 2019 in 44 local markets in the United States.

Subsection Title: Impact Marketing Solutions / Gracenote Content Solutions
Subsubsection Text: _Impact Marketing Solutions_ Our impact solutions validate how effectively marketers invested to reach and influence audiences to take certain actions such as endorse a brand, subscribe to a service or make a purchase. Our portfolio spans pre-flight advertising intelligence and cross-platform media planning, in-flight audience activation and post-flight advertising effectiveness measurement. Marketers leverage Nielsen modeling in subsequent investment decisions. We offer over 20,000 syndicated segments representing different demographics, psychographics, media consumption and buying behavior along with thousands of additional custom segments. These audience segments describe individuals with a high propensity of exhibiting future behaviors such as purchasing a specific car model, a financial product, airline tickets and more. We enable these segments in a vast array of platforms currently connected to Nielsen’s Data Management Platform. Some key portfolio products include Total Media Resonance, Impact’s flagship solution, which offers cross-channel comparisons, delivers campaign effectiveness results and can answer how well a marketing campaign ----- resonates with a target audience by using brand funnel metrics like awareness, consideration, intent and loyalty, and Nielsen Marketing Cloud, a platform for the custom creation of audiences and activation of those audiences for digital campaign delivery. Some additional portfolio products include Nielsen Ad Intel, Nielsen Media Impact, and Nielsen Audience Planner, among others. We have pioneered the transition of demographic only insights to purchase behavior enhanced metrics, delivering the broadest and deepest coverage of ROI and Media Planning across various industries. NCS, our joint venture with Catalina Marketing Corporation, and Nielsen Buyer Insights, are utilized by many major media companies in the United States for upfronts, research, industry events and everyday negotiations. Impact also contains Nielsen Sports, a global leader in sports media valuation, data intelligence and strategy and insights, along with Sports Connect and NFI. _Gracenote Content Solutions_ Gracenote Content is the leading metadata provider worldwide for video, music and sports that enables audience discovery of content and drives key business decision-making around content. Using a combination of machine learning and human editors, Gracenote creates, collects, normalizes and organizes the world’s entertainment data across TV shows, movies, celebrities, sports, teams, athletes, artists, albums and tracks, and provides entertainment metadata, content IDs and related offerings to the world’s leading content creators, distributors and platforms. At its core, we help customers connect their users with digital entertainment by making media more accessible and discoverable, driving engagement and loyalty. Gracenote data enables powerful analytics solutions, which help inform decisions around content development, acquisition and distribution. Gracenote ID is a standard for routing and monetizing content. Its global entertainment data portfolio features descriptions of more than 100 million music tracks, TV listings across 87 countries plus factual data and imagery for tens of millions of video programs, as well as statistics across more than 70 sports and 300,000 games each year. Additionally, as of the end of 2021, over 250 million vehicles have shipped globally that use Gracenote metadata in their in-car entertainment systems.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to develop innovative services that align with the evolving media landscape
Subsubsection Text: We are continuing to evolve our portfolio to align with ongoing change in the media landscape, allowing us to best empower our clients with actionable intelligence that enables them to engage with their audiences—now and in the future. In One Measurement Solutions, we are advancing on our roadmap to deliver a single, cross-media measurement solution, Nielsen ONE, which will enable the industry to transact using a single metric across linear, digital and streaming that is trusted, independent and standardized. In Impact Marketing Solutions, we are innovating with new services and focused on unlocking the value of connecting measurement of audiences to measurement of impact. In Gracenote Content Services, we are focused on launching new products to help distributors analyze, benchmark and derive insights from their catalogs.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to attract new clients and expand existing relationships
Subsubsection Text: We believe that substantial opportunities exist to both attract new clients and to increase our revenue from existing clients across our three essential solutions. Building on our deep knowledge, we expect to sell new and innovative solutions to new and existing clients, increasing our importance to their decision making processes. Over the past several years, Nielsen has experienced rapid growth with many of the leading technology and digital media companies, and these fast-growing entities represent a growing share of Nielsen’s revenue, with revenue from select digital customers growing at a CAGR of approximately 30% from 2019 to 2021.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to grow outside the United States
Subsubsection Text: International revenues comprised approximately 18% of 2021 revenues. Nielsen has a presence in more than 55 countries, which creates an entry point to grow in many of these countries across all three strategic pillars. Many of our clients are global and we have the opportunity to expand internationally with these clients. In particular, our Impact and Gracenote offerings can serve as beachheads for the broader Measurement business in new geographies. We expect our international businesses to grow faster than our US business over the next several years.

Subsubsection Title: Continue to pursue strategic acquisitions to complement our leadership positions
Subsubsection Text: We have increased our capabilities through investments and acquisitions in the United States and international audience measurement, and advertising effectiveness for digital media campaigns. Going forward, we will consider select acquisitions of complementary businesses that enhance our product and geographic portfolio and can benefit from our scale, scope and status as a global leader.

We believe we are well-positioned for growth globally and have a multi-faceted digital-first and global-first strategy that aligns with the evolving media landscape—both the rapid growth of the industry and where it is going. Our strategy is to measure all media consumption, everywhere, at all times and centers around our three strategic pillars: One Measurement Solutions; Impact Marketing Solutions; and Gracenote Content Services. -----

Subsubsection Title: Large and growing underlying market
Subsubsection Text: We primarily operate in the large and growing U.S. advertising market. According to MoffettNathanson, 2022 estimated U.S. advertising spend is $315 billion, with our main market segments—TV and Digital Video— representing about 25% and 12% of the market, respectively. The TV market, which encompasses both Linear TV and AVOD players, remains the primary medium for broad based audience reach, with entrenched viewership of live events like sports, politics and live news, and is expected to grow at a CAGR of 3.2% from 2021 to 2025, according to research from MoffettNathanson. At the same time, the Digital Video market is expected to grow at a CAGR of 15% from 2021 to 2025. This rapid growth is a major driver of overall future advertising spending, creating a distinct need to evaluate Digital Video against the primary advertising medium of TV and a major addressable growth driver for our products and services. ----- Source: MoffettNathanson and eMarketer. (1) Includes YouTube, Snap and portions of other social media platforms. (2) Includes search, Google Network, and portions of social media platforms. (3) Includes Newspapers, Magazines and Outdoor. Under the ongoing media fragmentation, viewers have more choice and the landscape is growing increasingly complex. Core television viewing is shifting to streaming and it is much tougher to quantify the times of day aspect that previously existed. According to research from eMarketer, U.S. time spent with audio and linear video will decrease at a CAGR of approximately 1% and approximately 8%, respectively, from 2021 to 2025, while time spent with digital content will grow at a CAGR of 6% over the same time period. The demand for our service to help navigate this much more complex environment has increased with the growing relevance of digital-first players and TV clients leaning in as they shift to streaming, blurring the lines between TV and digital. This mix shift increases the importance of having deduplicated view of reach and frequency across platforms, which we believe we are best positioned to provide through Nielsen ONE.

Subsubsection Title: Resilient, highly profitable business model driven by currency of choice status in media measurement
Subsubsection Text: We believe we are the independent, third-party provider of measurement data that serves as the U.S. media market currency of choice for transacting in advertising. We are deeply embedded at every step of the advertising value chain and provide myriad further benefits to clients, such as historical like-for-like comparability with over 50 years of Nielsen transactional metrics and easy embedding into networks’ and advertisers’ technology platforms. Our status in the market and offering to customers is underpinned by an unmatched asset base, including our gold standard panel. Our panel provides the gold-standard of measurement, as it is the only measurement capable of accurately measuring person-level viewing and confirmed viewership, correcting errors and biases to provide far more accurate and detailed metrics than big data or third-party census data. Additionally, our panel is the only dataset of sufficient scale to provide statistically significant and representative national and local TV measurement, alongside the granularity and deduplication necessary to capture both total audience and individual numbers. We supplement this gold-standard panel data with the industry’s largest collection of big data, led by a team of more than 500 data scientists. These data scientists oversee the ingestion of more than 14 petabytes of data from more than 7 billion transactions per day via CTV, STB and digital platforms across approximately 35 million households. Our data is cleaned and validated with an identity graph of more than 1 billion devices and 175 million persons and proprietary people-based panels consisting of more than 500,000 people. Some of our competitors are competing aggressively in specialty niches or added supplementary services. We offer, however, a comprehensive solution across many major key performance indicators. Ultimately, we ----- believe the scale and rigor of our panel, built over decades, make us the currency of choice in the U.S. media market.

Subsubsection Title: Highly recurring revenue model with consistent growth
Subsubsection Text: Our leading positioning is supported by consistent revenue growth and a high reliance on Nielsen’s products among major media clients as the media landscape evolves. Within U.S. media measurement, many contracts are designed as multi-year commitments with annual price escalators and staggered across different expiration years, such that no single year has outsized renewal exposure. This model allows us to enjoy high revenue visibility, with approximately 80% contracted revenue (meaning that 80% of the revenue base entering a given year is already committed under contract), and approximately 85% of Measurement revenue contracted, leading to insulation from recessionary declines. Consequently, we experienced minimal revenue pressure during both the Global Financial Crisis and COVID-19, with modest underperformance during COVID-19 driven by short-cycle revenue declines in uncontracted, non-measurement revenue like sports and automotive. Our revenue retention is bolstered by long term client relationships and minimal churn. Of our top five clients, the average length of relationship is more than 30 years. These top five clients accounted for approximately 23% of 2021 revenue and no client accounted for more than 10% or more of our revenue in the same year. Additionally, 100% of our top 10 clients have renewed contracts within the last 3 years. The majority of minimal churn stems from customer closure, especially in shrinking markets like linear local measurement, and bespoke consultancy projects in the Impact division which do not repeat. (1) Reflects organic constant-currency growth, which removes both the net effect of business acquisitions and divestitures and foreign currency exchange rate impact of current segmentation of Media revenue. Metrics disclosed from 2016 onward. (2) Reflects constant-currency revenue growth of former and current segmentation of Media revenue. Constant currency revenue removes the foreign currency exchange rate impact.

Subsubsection Title: Operational improvement opportunities
Subsubsection Text: We have identified and intend to implement a robust set of cost savings opportunities that will improve our operating efficiency and better align the Company’s cost structure with our long-term strategic goals. We expect approximately $185 million of annualized cost savings as a part of the Transactions. These cost savings opportunities extend across several functional areas of the business. Commercial expense savings are driven by the rightsizing of the existing salesforce to reflect and incorporate a more unified Nielsen ONE measurement methodology as well as a reduction in low performer headcount. Operations expense savings are generated though optimization of panelist recruitment and maintenance practices as well as adoption of further automation in customer care. Apart from these expense categories, we expect additional cost savings associated with streamlining backoffice operations, offshoring initiatives and offshoring third-party vendor spend. None of these identified reductionsin-force are related to the Nielsen ONE organization and the streamlining initiatives will benefit the Company’s transformation objectives. We expect these cost savings initiatives will begin to be actioned upon consummation of ----- the Transactions and will continue over the next 18 to 24 months. Even if we are able to execute the Transactions successfully, this may not result in the full realization of the cost savings that we currently expect, and therefore, we cannot assure you that any anticipated cost savings will be achieved or that our estimates and assumptions will prove to be accurate. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Acquisition—We may be unable to realize anticipated cost savings and expect to incur substantial expenses related to the Acquisition, which could have a material adverse effect on our business, financial condition and results of operations.”

Subsubsection Title: Strong free cash flow generation
Subsubsection Text: We have generated a cumulative $3,338 million of Adjusted free cash flow since the beginning of 2019 through 2021, with Pro forma adjusted free cash flow of $1,345 million for the twelve months ended September 30, 2022, and have consistently demonstrated strong free cash flow generation since 2019, expanding our Adjusted free cash flow conversion from 62.5% in 2019 to 77.3% in 2021. This is due in part to our resilient high-margin business model as well as our disciplined approach towards capital expenditures. Although capital expenditures have grown over the past few quarters due to increasing investments in Nielsen ONE development and meters (e.g., Set Meters, People Meters, Active/Passive Meters, PPM’s), we believe the eventual rollout of Nielsen ONE and broader organizational simplification will enable us to reduce capital expenditures in the longer-term. Additionally, we believe the rollout of Nielsen ONE will continue to strengthen our market-leading position and drive additional revenue through the business. Apart from this, we have had cash inflows from working capital over the past several years and do not expect significant working capital needs as our business grows going forward, which further support free cash flow generation. ----- (1) Please see Adjusted EBITDA reconciliation in “Summary—Summary Historical Consolidated and Unaudited Pro Forma Condensed Consolidated Financial Information.” (2) Represents Capital Expenditures from continuing operations. (3) Adjusted Free Cash Flow defined as Adjusted EBITDA less Capital Expenditures; Adjusted Free Cash Flow Conversion defined as (Adjusted EBITDA less Capital Expenditures) / Adjusted EBITDA. LTM 9/30/222 calculated using Pro forma adjusted EBITDA.

Subsubsection Title: Talented and experienced management team
Subsubsection Text: We are fortunate to boast a management team with decades of leadership experience across the media and technology industry. Our Chief Executive Officer, David Kenny, has previously served as President of Akamai, Chief Executive Officer of The Weather Company, and Senior Vice President of Cognitive Solutions at IBM; Mr. Kenny has a proven track record of implementing large-scale growth strategies and creating value for stakeholders. Mr. Kenny, in partnership with Nielsen’s broader management team, has been driving forward the Company’s operating plan and transformation strategy amidst the changing industry landscape.

Our technology has undergone a major transformation in the last three years. The majority of the Measurement and Gracenote Infrastructure is Cloud Native and is hosted on Amazon Web Services. The bedrock of our Measurement products is the Media Platform and the Media Data Lake that processes and hosts 25 Petabytes of Nielsen data. The Media Platform plays an instrumental role in meeting service commitments to global clients and allows us to quickly scale our services across practice areas and geographies. The platform utilizes an open approach that facilitates integration of distinct data sets, interoperability with client data and technology, and partnerships with leading technology companies.

Our patents, trademarks, trade secrets, copyrights and all of our other intellectual property are important assets that afford protection to our business. Our success depends to a degree upon our ability to protect and preserve certain proprietary aspects of our technology and our brand. To ensure that objective, we control and limit access to our proprietary technology. Our employees and consultants enter into confidentiality, non-disclosure and invention assignment agreements with us. We protect our rights to proprietary technology and confidential information in our business arrangements with third parties through confidentiality and other intellectual property and business agreements. We hold a number of third-party patent and intellectual property license agreements that afford us rights to third-party patents, technology and other intellectual property. Such license agreements most often do not preclude either party from licensing our patents and technology to others. Such licenses may involve one-time payments or ongoing royalty obligations, and we cannot ensure that future license agreements can or will be obtained or renewed on acceptable terms, or at all. Pursuant to the Stock Purchase Agreement, we entered into certain ancillary agreements at the closing of the Connect Transaction. We granted Advent a license to brand its products and services with the “Nielsen” name and other Nielsen trademarks for 20 years following the closing of the Connect Transaction. Additionally, Nielsen and Advent entered into agreements pursuant to which, among other things, Nielsen and Advent (i) granted each other reciprocal licenses for certain data and corresponding services relating to that data for periods of up to five years following the closing and (ii) granted each other licenses to use certain patents and other intellectual property.

There is no single competitor that offers all of the services we offer in all of the markets in which we offer them. We have many competitors worldwide that offer some of the services we provide in selected markets. While we maintain leading positions in many markets in which we operate, our future success will depend on our ability to enhance and expand our suite of services, provide reliable and accurate measurement solutions and related information, drive innovation that anticipates and responds to emerging client needs, strengthen and expand our geographic footprint, and protect consumer privacy. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Competition.” We believe our ability to provide an independent, holistic view of the media landscape, our global presence, and our integrated ----- portfolio of services across our three strategic pillars are key assets in our ability to effectively compete in the marketplace. We are a clear market leader in U.S. television audience measurement and believe we are uniquely positioned to deliver a single cross-media measurement solution that will deliver comparable and comprehensive metrics across all platforms. However, there are many emerging players and technologies that will increase competitive pressure across our portfolio of solutions. Numerous companies, such as Comscore are attempting to provide alternative forms of television audience measurement using, inter alia, set-top box data and panel-based measurement. Our principal competitor in television audience measurement outside the United States is Kantar, with companies such as GfK and Ipsos also providing competition in select individual countries. Our primary competitors in the digital audience and campaign measurement space in the United States are Comscore, LiveRamp, Oracle, The Trade Desk and iSpot.tv. Our principal competitors globally are Kantar, GFK, and Ipsos. Outside the United States, Kantar, GFK and Ipsos use a variety of electronic and recall based measurement approaches that are similar in some ways to Nielsen’s technologies. We are the market leader in U.S. audio audience measurement. Our principal competitor for Radio audience measurement in the United States is Eastlan Ratings who uses telephone recall based approach and their services are primarily sold in smaller markets. Additionally Triton, a U.S.-based digital competitor, has a streaming Audio and Podcast measurement service that uses server log technology. Triton was acquired by iHeartMedia in February 2021. Within the Impact portfolio landscape, vendors have come and gone over the years as large industry changes such as privacy regulation and data deprecation have created massive hurdles for vendors to overcome. In recent years, key competitors include Analytic Partners, Neustar, IpsosMMA, Gain Theory and IRI. Gracenote is the premier provider of entertainment metadata globally. On the video and music fronts, we primarily compete with Xperi which owns TiVo. Gracenote also competes with Red Bee Media and Mediapresse mainly in video across a number of international markets. We also sell our products against various single-market competitors and some in-house solutions. Gracenote’s competition on the sports front comes from Stats Perform and Sportradar. In the area of content analytics, we compete with Whip Media and Parrot Analytics.

We are subject to a variety of laws and regulations in the United States and abroad that involve matters central to our business, many of which are still evolving, and could be interpreted in ways that could harm our business. These laws and regulations may involve privacy, data use, cross-border data transfers, data protection, intellectual property, securities law, COVID-19 related compliance, taxation, labor laws or other subjects. There is a trend toward regulations requiring companies to provide consumers with greater information regarding, and greater control over, how their personal data is used and shared, as well as requiring notification when unauthorized access to such data occurs. These privacy and data protection laws and regulations, which in some cases can be enforced by private parties in addition to government entities, are constantly evolving and can be subject to significant change. As a result, the application, interpretation, and enforcement of these laws and regulations are often uncertain, and may be applied, interpreted and enforced differently in different jurisdictions, and may be inconsistent with our current policies and practices. For additional information about government regulation applicable to our business, see “Risk Factors— Risks Related to Cybersecurity and Privacy” and “—Risks Relating to Governmental or Regulatory Change” in this offering memorandum. -----

As part of Nielsen’s mission to power a better media future for all people, we strive every day to engage our people, processes, data and technology to make Nielsen a more responsible company and to enable a more equitable world, where everyone is included and everyone counts. Nielsen is committed to strengthening the communities and markets in which we live and operate our business, recognizing how important these efforts are to ensure a more equitable and sustainable future. This commitment is supported and expressed at all levels of our organization. Our ESG strategy encompasses the most important factors that affect our business, operations and internal and external stakeholders. To determine which ESG issues are of greatest importance to our company and our stakeholders, we regularly conduct an ESG issues assessment, with our fourth such assessment completed in December 2021. We continue to identify and prioritize issues, impacts, risks and opportunities for Nielsen and to develop a more concise input to our ESG strategy. We report across six key topics: diversity, equity and inclusion, human capital, data privacy and security, community engagement, environment and governance. While it is the responsibility of all teams within Nielsen to consider relevant ESG impacts in their everyday work, we aim to approach ESG risks and opportunities in a holistic way through our strategy, infusing these considerations into regular engagement with our management team, internal working groups, across functional groups and teams and other forums.

Subsubsection Title: Employees
Subsubsection Text: As of December 31, 2021, we employed approximately 15,000 people worldwide, which includes approximately 1,000 part-time employees. We have approximately 6,200 employees in the United States, 1,200 in the remaining Americas, 2,900 in Europe, and 4,500 in the Asia/Pacific/Middle East/Africa (“APMEA”) regions. Approximately 4% of our employees are covered under collective bargaining agreements. Approximately 7% are covered under works council agreements in Europe.

Subsubsection Title: Compensation and Benefits
Subsubsection Text: Nielsen is committed to providing appropriate, competitive and equitable pay and benefits for all associates, commensurate with the work being performed and in accordance with applicable laws and regulations. Our associates are rewarded and promoted based on performance against priorities and how they demonstrate the Nielsen values. Our pay philosophy is to provide a total compensation package that is market-competitive based on data provided by independent third parties and that also provides an opportunity for pay growth and role progression based on individual contribution and company performance.

Subsubsection Title: Talent Development and Associate Engagement
Subsubsection Text: We work to integrate associates into Nielsen from day one by helping new associate hires understand our culture, be clear on their roles and feel connected to their new team and to the broader Nielsen community. We offer mentoring programs that provide valuable learning, development and networking experiences, matching associates with mentors who can support their personal and professional development objectives. We offer a skill development platform to all employees. Our policy is to maintain well-developed communications and consultation programs with all employees and employee representative bodies, including via email communication or regular updates of our internal communication platform and channels. We also inform and consult with recognized unions and works councils as ----- appropriate. We continually seek feedback from our employees through Leadership Townhalls, pulse surveys, and engagement surveys conducted through a third-party provider.

Subsubsection Title: Diversity, Equity and Inclusion (“DE&I”)
Subsubsection Text: We power a better media future for all people by embracing, leveraging and incorporating diversity, equity and inclusion in all that we do. When we operate in a culture that is diverse and inclusive, our hope is that innovation flourishes, our clients win, and associates are engaged and collaborate to bring the best that Nielsen can offer to the diverse audiences that we measure. Nielsen’s DE&I strategy covers four pillars: _People_ - We aim to build a globally inclusive and impactful culture at Nielsen. This means increasing diverse representation among employees, providing equitable growth opportunities for diverse employees, hiring from diverse talent pools and expanding our inclusive hiring practices. We have set public 2024 goals for representation of women in global leadership, U.S. Black mid-level leadership and U.S. Hispanic leadership. - We are investing in diverse talent development programs, including leadership development cohorts to help us meet our representation goals and the Diverse Leadership Network (“DLN”), a 12-month leadership development program designed to strengthen and diversify our leadership pipeline. - We support 14 internal business resource groups (“BRGs”), with over 3,500 members around the world. Our BRGs engage employees in programming that drives Nielsen’s advocacy, educational outreach and business growth, which results in increased impact on local business and the communities where we work. _Product & Thought Leadership_ - Building on our role as the trusted source of measurement on media behaviors, content attributes, and industry trends across all platforms, we focus on diverse insights and inclusive intelligence to better understand the audience. - Through thought leadership, we aim to address the industry’s critical questions around diversity, equity and inclusion, using Nielsen’s products and solutions that measure audiences and content. - In February 2022, we launched a Diverse Media Equity program. As part of our commitment to creating a better media future for all people, we expect to raise the visibility of diverse-owned media that play a critical role in reaching and representing the increasingly diverse population. _Business Diversity_ - Nielsen’s values-inclusion, courage, growth-are the foundation of our business. Our mission is to buy better: to engage, include and contract with diverse business partners who have the perspectives, expertise and products/services that will help us create a better media future for all people. - We track and report diverse spend and have multiple policies and processes to support a corporate goal of 15% U.S. spend with diverse businesses by the end of 2022. In 2020, we exceeded our corporate goal of 10% of U.S. sourceable spend on diverse suppliers and subsequently set a new goal of 15% by 2022. In 2021, we met that 15% with $104 million in spending with diverse suppliers. Our continued goal is to maintain our 15% target through 2024, with a stretch goal of 18%. ----- _Community Advocacy_ - In the markets where we do business, we nurture relationships with community leaders and organizations, such as the LEAD Network and Valuable 500 so that we can best serve diverse communities. - To ensure that we have an outside-in perspective, we created an External Advisory Council (“EAC”) representing media industry leaders from diverse communities. The EAC provides input, ideas, recommendations and opportunities through a DE&I lens to benefit our people, work, clients and communities.

Subsubsection Title: Health and Safety
Subsubsection Text: We maintain a commitment to health and wellbeing. Nielsen’s benefit offerings are designed to meet the varied and evolving needs of a diverse workforce across businesses and geographies. We have enhanced the ways we help our employees care for themselves and their families, especially in response to COVID-19. Our Whole You health and wellbeing program focuses not just on physical health, but also on the emotional, financial, social and environmental well-being of our associates. The Whole You well-being program was created in 2015 to provide support for our employees and their families in meaningful, contemporary and progressive ways. Since 2015, the program has evolved to meet the needs of our diverse population globally. Most recently, the program changed to a new virtual delivery method to address the global pandemic reality. The Whole You program offers a mix of US and global initiatives, such as step and activity challenges, webinars and training sessions. A key component of The Whole You is our group of well-being ambassadors (employee volunteers) who promote global, national and local well-being initiatives.

Subsubsection Title: COVID-19
Subsubsection Text: We employ several strategies intended to address issues arising during the COVID-19 pandemic, including COVID-19 safety protocols for all employees that are consistent with the guidance of local health authorities, remote working arrangements where possible, company-provided personal protective equipment (“PPE”) and training, facilities management policies, workplace safety committees, supplemental paid sick leave (U.S.) and ongoing health benefits reviews. We implemented programs to reduce barriers to COVID-19 vaccination access including supplemental paid time off for the purposes of an employee/dependent receiving a vaccine and local partnership to increase access to vaccination, as needed on a market-by-market basis. In addition, Nielsen offers employee emergency financial support through the Nielsen Global Support Fund, through which associates can donate to fellow associates in need and apply for grants in times of personal hardship or natural disaster. -----

Our key human capital management objectives are to promote the health, wellness, and safety of our employees while building an inclusive and engaging culture where all of our employees have an equal opportunity to reach their full potential.

The following table sets forth certain information regarding the individuals who serve as the executive officers of the Company. The board of directors of the Company is comprised of 12 members, including members affiliated with the Equity Investors and certain minority investors. In connection with the consummation of the Acquisition, the Equity Investors appointed the board of directors, and the board of directors is controlled by the Equity Investors. Additional directors may also be appointed to the board of directors.

David Kenny .................................. 60 Chief Executive Officer George Callard ............................... 59 Chief Legal and Corporate Affairs Officer Henry Iglesias ................................ 50 Controller & Principal Accounting Officer Laurie Lovett .................................. 55 Chief People Officer Karthik Rao .................................... 49 Chief Operating Officer Linda Zukauckas ............................ 60 Chief Financial Officer (*) Age as of September 22, 2022.

Subsection Title: David Kenny has been the Chief Executive Officer of Nielsen since December 2018. Prior to that time,
Subsubsection Text: Mr. Kenny served as Senior Vice President of Cognitive Solutions at IBM, joining IBM in January 2016, after its acquisition of The Weather Company’s Product and Technology Business. Previously, from January 2012 until 2016, Mr. Kenny served as Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of The Weather Company. Prior to The Weather Company, Mr. Kenny was President of Akamai, the cloud service provider, and the co-founder, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the digital marketing agency Digitas, which was a Nasdaq listed company before its sale to Publicis Groupe in 2007. Mr. Kenny began his career as a consultant at Bain & Company, where he rose to the Partner level. Mr. Kenny serves on the Board of Directors of Teach for America.

Subsection Title: George Callard has been the Chief Legal and Corporate Affairs Officer of Nielsen since January 2019.
Subsubsection Text: Prior to joining Nielsen, Mr. Callard served as President of Weather Group, LLC from July 2018 to January 2019. From 2016 to 2018, Mr. Callard served as Chief Administrative Officer & General Counsel at Weather Group, LLC. From 2013 to 2015, he served as EVP, General Counsel & Head of Government Affairs for The Weather Company, parent company of The Weather Channel. Previously, Mr. Callard served as vice president of legal and business affairs at NBCU and had two tenures with AT&T (SBC & Ameritech). Earlier in his career, he served as counsel and assistant secretary and as senior counsel at the law firm Cinnamon Mueller and associate counsel for Multimedia Cablevision.

Subsection Title: Henry Iglesias has been the Controller of Nielsen since January 2022 and the Principal Accounting Officer
Subsubsection Text: of Nielsen since March 2022. Mr. Iglesias was the Vice President, Financial Planning & Analysis and Global Sales Finance at Tiffany & Co., the global luxury jeweler, from October 2018 through April 2021, and prior to that time, Vice President, Financial Planning & Analysis at Tiffany & Co. from June 2013 to October 2018. Mr. Iglesias held various leadership roles at Tiffany & Co., including Vice President, Interim Treasurer and Vice President, Corporate Controller and Principal Accounting Officer. He previously worked for PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP.

Subsection Title: Laurie Lovett has been the Chief People Officer of Nielsen since January 2020. Prior to joining Nielsen,
Subsubsection Text: Ms. Lovett was the Global Chief Human Resources Officer at Verisk Analytics from April 2016 through October 2019. Prior to joining Verisk Analytics, from January 1996 to March 2016, Ms. Lovett spent over 20 years with Accenture, holding various leadership roles.

Subsection Title: Karthik Rao has been the Chief Operating Officer of Nielsen since March 2021. Mr. Rao has served at
Subsubsection Text: Nielsen for over twenty years in a variety of leadership roles spanning the United States, Middle East and Asia. Mr. Rao was the Chief Operating Officer of Global Media from February 2020 to March 2021, and, prior to that, he served as Chief Product & Technology Officer of Global Media where he led the International Media product and technology teams. Previously, Mr. Rao was the CEO of Nielsen Portfolio, where he led the Nielsen Entertainment, ----- Nielsen Gracenote, Nielsen Brandbank and Nielsen Telecom businesses across all global markets. He led Gracenote during its acquisition and integration by Nielsen. Prior to Gracenote, he served as President, Expanded Verticals, and led the teams serving Nielsen’s advertiser and agency clients. Earlier in his career, Mr. Rao was Executive Vice President of Digital Enablement, where he oversaw a global transformation program. He also led Nielsen’s Media Analytics business and was head of Nielsen China. Mr. Rao began his career as an account executive at Ogilvy & Mather in India. Mr. Rao serves on the Board of Directors of Blucora, Inc.

Subsection Title: Linda Zukauckas has been the Chief Financial Officer of Nielsen since February 2020 and expects to
Subsubsection Text: remain with Nielsen until January 2023. The Company is currently undertaking a search to replace Ms. Zukauckas that includes both internal and external candidates. Prior to joining Nielsen, Ms. Zukauckas was the Executive Vice President and Deputy Chief Financial Officer for American Express from February 2018 to January 2020. She had previously served as EVP/Controller and Chief Accounting Officer of American Express since November 2011. From 2000 to 2011, Ms. Zukauckas held various senior finance roles at Ally Financial, including strategy/M&A, divisional CFO, head of corporate planning, global controller/Chief Accounting Officer and global head of internal audit. From 1997 to 2000, Ms. Zukauckas held various positions at Deutsche Bank, where she rose to the position of chief auditor for the Global Investment Bank. She began her career with PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP in 1984 and held progressive leadership roles there. Ms. Zukauckas serves on the Board of Directors of Zelis Healthcare Inc. -----

Global economic conditions will continue to be volatile as long as the COVID-19 pandemic remains a public health threat because of various factors including, as a result of new information concerning the severity of the pandemic, government actions to mitigate the effects of the pandemic in the near-term, the severity and spread of new variants of the virus and their resistance to current vaccines and treatments, the approval of new treatments and vaccines, and the resulting impact on our business and operations and sales and customer demand. We expect global economic performance and the performance of our businesses to vary by geography and discipline until the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on the global economy subsides. For further discussion regarding the potential impacts of COVID-19 and related economic conditions on Nielsen, see “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the COVID-19 Pandemic, Environment and Other External Factors.”

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN OTHER INDEBTEDNESS Debt Facilities
Subsubsection Title: First Lien Debt Facilities
Subsubsection Text: To finance the Acquisition and related transactions, we entered into (a) the First Lien Credit Agreement and the First Lien Credit Facilities thereunder, which provides for (i) the 1L Term A Facility, (ii) the Dollar Term Loan Facilities, (iii) the Euro Term Facility and (iv) a senior secured revolving credit facility in an aggregate principal amount equal to $650 million, (b) the Second Lien Credit Agreement, which provides for the Second Lien Facility, and (c) the Bridge Credit Agreement, which provides for the Bridge Facility. Affiliates of each of the initial purchasers are lenders under the First Lien Credit Facilities. _Interest Rate and Fees_ Amounts borrowed under the First Lien Debt Facilities are subject to an interest rate per annum equal to (a) an applicable margin of (i) for base rate loans (A) under the New Revolving Facility in Dollars, if the Issuer’s first lien leverage ratio is (1) greater than 4.40 to 1.00, 3.50%, (2) less than or equal to 4.40 to 1.00 and greater than 3.90 to 1.00, 3.25% and (3) less than or equal to 3.90 to 1.00, 3.00%, (B) under the 1L Term B Facility, 4.00%, and (C) under the 1L Term A Facility, 3.75%, (ii) for Term SOFR rate loans (A) under the New Revolving Facility in Dollars, if the Issuer’s first lien leverage ratio is (1) greater than 4.40 to 1.00, 4.50%, (2) less than or equal to 4.40 to 1.00 and greater than 3.90 to 1.00, 4.25% and (3) less than or equal to 3.90 to 1.00, 4.00%, (B) under 1L Term B Facility, 5.00%, and (C) under the 1L Term A Facility, 4.75%, (iii) for EURIBOR rate loans (A) under the New Revolving Facility in Euros, if the Issuer’s first lien leverage ratio is (1) greater than 4.40 to 1.00, 4.50%, (2) less than or equal to 4.40 to 1.00 and greater than 3.90 to 1.00, 4.25% and (3) less than or equal to 3.90 to 1.00, 4.00%, and (B) under the Euro Term Facility, 5.00%, and (iv) for SONIA rate loans under the New Revolving Facility in British pound sterling, if the Issuer’s first lien leverage ratio is (1) greater than 4.40 to 1.00, 4.50%, (2) less than or equal to 4.40 to 1.00 and greater than 3.90 to 1.00, 4.25% and (3) less than or equal to 3.90 to 1.00, 4.00%, plus (b)(i) for base rate loans, a base rate determined by reference to the highest of (A) the rate of interest publicly identified, from time to time as the U.S. “prime rate” as published in the Money Rates section of the Wall Street Journal, (B) the Federal Funds Rate plus 0.50% and (C) one month term SOFR plus 1.00%, (ii) for term SOFR rate loans (A) under the Revolving Facility in Dollars, the higher of (1) a rate determined by reference to the term SOFR rate based on the interest period of the applicable borrowing and (2) a floor and (B) under the Dollar Term Loan Facility, the higher of (1) a rate determined by reference to the term SOFR rate based on the interest period of the applicable borrowing and (2) a floor, (iii) for EURIBOR rate loans under the Revolving Facility in Euros or the Euro Term Loan Facility, the higher of (A) a rate determined by reference to the EURIBOR rate based on the interest period of the applicable borrowing, and (B) a floor or (iv) for SONIA rate loans under the Revolving Facility in British pound sterling, the higher of (A) a rate determined by reference to the Sterling Overnight Index Average and (B) a floor. _Mandatory Repayments_ The First Lien Credit Agreement requires us to prepay outstanding loans under the Term Loan Facilities, subject to certain exceptions and thresholds, with: (1) 100% of the net cash proceeds of any incurrence of debt not permitted under the First Lien Credit Agreement and debt incurred to refinance the First Lien Debt Facilities, (2) 50% (which percentage may be reduced to 25% and 0% if our first lien leverage ratio is less than or equal to specified levels) of our annual excess cash flow (as defined in the First Lien Credit Agreement) minus certain deductions applicable thereto and (3) 100% (which percentage may be reduced to 50% and 0% if our first lien leverage ratio is less than or equal to specified levels) of the net cash proceeds of certain non-ordinary course asset sales or other dispositions of property by the Issuer or by any of its restricted subsidiaries, subject to reinvestment rights and certain other exceptions and thresholds. ----- _Voluntary Repayments_ We are able to voluntarily prepay outstanding loans under the First Lien Debt Facilities at any time without premium or penalty, other than a premium of 1.00% applicable to any prepayment of the Term Loan Facility that is made in connection with a “repricing transaction” that occurs on or prior to the 6-month anniversary of the effective date of the First Lien Debt Facilities, subject to certain exceptions. _Amortization and Final Maturity_ The Term Loan Facility amortizes at 1% per annum in equal quarterly installments, with the balance payable in 2029, at the time the Term Loan Facility matures. _Guarantees and Security_ The obligations under the First Lien Debt Facilities are unconditionally guaranteed by Parent and certain of the Issuer’s direct and indirect wholly-owned subsidiaries. All obligations under the First Lien Debt Facilities, and the guarantees of those obligations, are secured, subject to certain exceptions, by: - a pledge of 100% of the capital stock of the Issuer and each guarantor, subject to certain exceptions; and - a security interest in substantially all other tangible and intangible assets of the Issuer and each guarantor, subject to certain exceptions. The liens securing our obligations under the First Lien Debt Facilities are first priority liens on all of the relevant assets of the Issuer and the guarantors, subject to customary exceptions and liens permitted under the First Lien Debt Facilities. The liens securing our obligations under the Second Lien Term Loan are second priority liens on all of the relevant assets of the Issuer and the guarantors, subject to customary exceptions and liens permitted under the Second Lien Term Loan. _Certain Covenants and Events of Default_ The First Lien Debt Facilities contain a number of covenants that, among other things and subject to certain exceptions and thresholds, restrict the ability of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries to, among others: - incur additional indebtedness, including capital leases; - pay dividends on capital stock or redeem, repurchase or retire capital stock or other indebtedness; - make investments, loans, advances and acquisitions; - enter into burdensome agreements with negative pledge clauses or clauses restricting subsidiary distributions; - engage in transactions with our affiliates; - sell assets, including the capital stock of our subsidiaries; - consolidate or merge; and - create liens. The First Lien Credit Agreement also contains a customary passive holding company covenant applicable to the Issuer. ----- The First Lien Credit Agreement contains a financial covenant, solely with respect to the Revolving Facility, of a maximum first lien leverage ratio set forth in the First Lien Credit Agreement, which financial covenant shall spring into effect while outstanding loans under the Revolving Facility exceed a certain threshold. The First Lien Credit Agreement also contains certain events of default, subject to cure provisions and trigger thresholds, including payment defaults, failure to perform or observe covenants, cross-defaults with certain other events of default in connection with our other material indebtedness, a change of control and certain bankruptcy events, among others.

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsection Title: DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN OTHER INDEBTEDNESS Debt Facilities
Subsubsection Title: Second Lien Term Loan
Subsubsection Text: To finance the Acquisition and related transactions, we, concurrently with the consummation of the Acquisition, entered into the Second Lien Term Loan. We used the proceeds of this offering and the borrowings under the First Lien Debt Facilities and Second Lien Term Loan, together with equity contributions from funds and other investment vehicles affiliated with the Equity Investors and other investors, (i) to pay the cash consideration for the Acquisition, (ii) to finance the repayment of substantially all of Nielsen’s existing outstanding indebtedness, (iii) to pay any related premiums, fees and expenses and (iv) for general corporate purposes. _Interest Rate and Fees_ Amounts borrowed under the Second Lien Term Loan are subject to an interest rate per annum equal to, at our option, either (i) for base rate loans, an applicable margin of 8.75% plus a base rate determined by reference to the highest of (A) the rate of interest publicly identified, from time to time as the U.S. “prime rate” as published in the Money Rates section of the Wall Street Journal, (B) the Federal Funds Rate plus 0.50% and (C) one month term SOFR plus 1.00%, or (ii) for term SOFR rate loans, an applicable margin of 9.75% plus a rate determined by reference to the higher of (A) the term SOFR rate based on the interest period of the applicable borrowing and (B) 0.75%. _Mandatory Repayments_ The Second Lien Credit Agreement requires us to prepay outstanding loans under the Second Lien Term Loan, subject to certain exceptions and thresholds, with: (1) 100% of the net cash proceeds of any incurrence of debt not permitted under the Second Lien Credit Agreement and debt incurred to refinance the Second Lien Term Loan and (2) 100% (which percentage may be reduced to 50% and 0% if our senior secured leverage ratio is less than or equal to specified levels) of the net cash proceeds of certain non-ordinary course asset sales or other dispositions of property by the Issuer or by any of its restricted subsidiaries, subject to reinvestment rights and certain other exceptions and thresholds. No mandatory prepayments of the Second Lien Term Loan shall be required until amounts outstanding under the Notes, the Dollar Term Loan Facility and the Euro Term Loan Facility have been paid in full. _Voluntary Repayments_ We are able to voluntarily prepay outstanding loans under the Second Lien Term Loan at any time, subject to the following premiums or penalties: (1) a customary “make whole” premium if such prepayment occurs on or prior to the one-year anniversary of effective date of the Second Lien Term Loan, (2) a premium of 2.00% if such prepayment occurs after the one-year anniversary of the effective date of the Second Lien Term Loan but on or prior to the two-year anniversary of the effective date of the Second Lien Term Loan and (3) a premium of 1.00% if such prepayment occurs after the two-year anniversary of the effective date of the Second Lien Term Loan but on or prior to the three-year anniversary of the effective date of the Second Lien Term Loan. _Amortization and Final Maturity_ The Second Lien Term Loan is not subject to amortization. The Second Lien Term Loan will mature on the date that is eight years after the effective date of the Second Lien Term Loan. ----- _Guarantees and Security_ The obligations under the Second Lien Term Loan are unconditionally guaranteed by Parent and certain of the Issuer’s direct and indirect wholly-owned subsidiaries. All obligations under the Second Lien Term Loan, and the guarantees of those obligations, are secured, subject to certain exceptions, by: - a pledge of 100% of the capital stock of the Issuer and each guarantor, subject to certain exceptions; and - a security interest in substantially all other tangible and intangible assets of the Issuer and each guarantor, subject to certain exceptions. The liens securing our obligations under the Second Lien Term Loan are second priority liens on all of the relevant assets of the Issuer and the guarantors, subject to customary exceptions and liens permitted under the Second Lien Term Loan. _Certain Covenants and Events of Default_ The Second Lien Term Loan contains a number of covenants that, among other things and subject to certain exceptions and thresholds, restrict the ability of the Issuer and its restricted subsidiaries to, among others: - incur additional indebtedness, including capital leases; - pay dividends on capital stock or redeem, repurchase or retire capital stock or other indebtedness; - make investments, loans, advances and acquisitions; - enter into burdensome agreements with negative pledge clauses or clauses restricting subsidiary distributions; - engage in transactions with our affiliates; - sell assets, including the capital stock of our subsidiaries; - consolidate or merge; - create liens; - layer debt, including retranching first lien debt; and - permit unrestricted subsidiaries to own material intellectual property. The Second Lien Credit Agreement also contains a customary passive holding company covenant applicable to the Issuer. The Second Lien Credit Agreement also contains certain events of default, subject to cure provisions and trigger thresholds, including payment defaults, failure to perform or observe covenants, cross-acceleration and crosspayment defaults at maturity in connection with the Notes and the First Lien Debt Facilities, and cross-defaults with certain other events of default in connection with our other material indebtedness, a change of control and certain bankruptcy events, among others. -----

Section Title: CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED PARTY TRANSACTIONS
Subsubsection Title: Nielsen Notes
Subsubsection Text: The 2025 Notes were issued pursuant to the indenture, dated as of January 31, 2017, as amended and supplemented through the date hereof, and will mature on February 1, 2025. The 2025 Notes currently bear interest at a rate of 5.000% per annum, payable on each February 1 and August 1. Approximately $10.9 million of 2025 Notes remain outstanding. The 2028 Notes were issued pursuant to the indenture, dated as of September 24, 2020, as amended and supplemented through the date hereof, and will mature on October 1, 2028. The 2028 Notes currently bear interest at a rate of 5.625% per annum, payable on each April 1 and October 1. Approximately $12.0 million of 2028 Notes remain outstanding. The 2029 Notes were issued pursuant to the indenture, dated as of May 28, 2021, as amended and supplemented through the date hereof, and will mature on July 15, 2029. The 2029 Notes currently bear interest at a rate of 4.500% per annum, payable on each January 15 and July 15. Approximately $3.5 million of 2029 Notes remain outstanding. The 2030 Notes were issued pursuant to the indenture, dated as of September 24, 2020, as amended and supplemented through the date hereof, and will mature on October 1, 2030. The 2030 Notes currently bear interest at a rate of 5.875% per annum, payable on each April 1 and October 1. Approximately $3.0 million of 2030 Notes remain outstanding. The 2031 Notes were issued pursuant to the indenture, dated as of May 28, 2021, as amended and supplemented through the date hereof, and will mature on July 15, 2031.
